turns.content: I woke up this morning feeling the whole room is spinning when i was sitting down. I went to the bathroom walking unsteadily, as i tried to focus i feel nauseous. I try to vomit but it wont come out.. After taking panadol and sleep for few hours, i still feel the same.. By the way, if i lay down or sit down, my head do not spin, only when i want to move around then i feel the whole world is spinning.. And it is normal stomach discomfort at the same time? Earlier after i relieved myself, the spinning lessen so i am not sure whether its connected or coincidences.. Thank you doc!

That spinning sensation triggered by movement sounds like vertigo, and I'm glad it improves when you're still. The nausea fits with this, and sometimes GI discomfort can accompany vertigo or be coincidental.

A few important questions:

1. Do you have any hearing loss, ringing in your ears, or ear fullness on either side?

2. Any severe headache, double vision, difficulty speaking, weakness, or numbness anywhere?

3. Have you had a recent cold, ear infection, or any head trauma in the past few days?

Now that you mention it, I did have a bit of a cold last week but it cleared up pretty quickly. As for your other questions, I haven't noticed any hearing loss, no ringing in my ears or feeling of fullness. I don't have any headaches, double vision, difficulty speaking, weakness or numbness either. Just this spinning and nausea really bothering me.

Good—no red-flag neurological symptoms is reassuring. Your recent cold and the positional spinning strongly suggest **benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV)** or possibly **vestibular neuritis**.

Three more quick questions:

1. Does the spinning last seconds (under a minute) or minutes to hours each time you move?

2. Which movements trigger it most—rolling over in bed, looking up, or bending down?

3. Any fever today, or did you have fever during your cold last week?

I'm not exactly sure how long the spinning lasts each time I move, but it feels like it's less than a minute most of the time. It's definitely the worst when I'm rolling over in bed or looking up. As for the fever, I don't think I have one today, and I don't remember having one when I had the cold last week. It's just really unsettling to feel like this.

That pattern—brief spinning (under a minute) triggered by rolling over or looking up—is classic for **BPPV**, where tiny crystals in your inner ear shift with head movement. The recent cold may have set it off.

**Plan:**

1. **Try the Epley maneuver** (search "Epley maneuver for BPPV" for videos)—it can reposition the crystals and often resolves symptoms in 1–2 sessions.
2. Stay hydrated and avoid sudden head movements for now.
3. If safe, have someone nearby when you first try the maneuver in case dizziness worsens temporarily.
4. Symptoms usually improve in days to a couple of weeks.

**Seek emergency care if** you develop severe headache, double vision, slurred speech, weakness, numbness, inability to walk, or if vertigo persists beyond 2 weeks without improvement.

Does this make sense, and do you feel comfortable trying the Epley maneuver at home?

Oh, that's a relief to hear. I was getting worried. I think I've seen that Epley maneuver thing on the internet but never thought it could help in my situation. I guess I'll give it a try then. Just to be clear, as long as I can handle the spinning, I don't need to go to the hospital, right? I mean, it's not like I'm having a stroke or something, right?

Correct—based on what you've told me, this doesn't sound like a stroke. Strokes causing dizziness usually come with other warning signs like the ones I mentioned (slurred speech, weakness, vision changes, severe headache, inability to walk). Your brief, movement-triggered spinning without those red flags points to an inner-ear issue, not a brain problem.

You don't need the hospital right now as long as you can safely move around at home and the symptoms match what we've discussed. Give the Epley maneuver a try—many people see improvement within a day or two. If the vertigo doesn't start improving in 3–4 days, gets worse, or you develop any of those red-flag symptoms, then get evaluated urgently.

Feel better, and reach out if anything changes!

My baby has been pooing 5-6 times a day for a week. In the last few days it has increased to 7 and they are very watery with green stringy bits in them. He does not seem unwell i.e no temperature and still eating. He now has a very bad nappy rash from the pooing ...help!

I understand your concern. The increased watery stools with green stringy bits and resulting nappy rash need attention, but it's reassuring he's still eating and has no fever.

A few key questions:

1. **How old is your baby?** And is he breastfed, formula-fed, or on solids?

2. **Are you noticing decreased wet nappies, dry lips/mouth, sunken eyes, or unusual sleepiness?** These would suggest dehydration.

3. **Has there been any recent antibiotic use, new foods introduced, or sick contacts at home or daycare?**

For now, continue feeding normally (breast or formula on demand). For the nappy rash: change frequently, clean gently with water, apply a thick barrier cream (zinc oxide), and allow nappy-free time if possible.

Oh, he just turned 6 months. We've been gradually introducing solids but mostly he's still on breast milk. His nappies are a bit less wet than usual, but nothing drastic... And no, he's not on antibiotics or anything. As for the nappy rash, I've been doing exactly what you said but it's not getting any better.

That timing with starting solids is important—this could be his gut adjusting to new foods, possibly a mild gastroenteritis, or even a cow's milk protein sensitivity if dairy has been introduced.

**Three more questions:**

1. **Which specific solid foods have you introduced, and when did you start each one?** Any dairy products like yogurt, cheese, or cow's milk in cooking?

2. **Is he still producing at least 4-6 wet nappies in 24 hours?** Does he seem his usual self between nappy changes—alert, playful, consolable?

3. **Can you describe the nappy rash—is it just red and raw, or are there raised bumps, white patches, or satellite spots around the main rash?**

If the rash has raised red bumps or satellite lesions, it may be a secondary yeast infection from the prolonged diarrhea, which needs antifungal cream rather than just barrier cream. Keep monitoring his hydration closely—if wet nappies drop further or he becomes lethargic, seek same-day assessment.

Oh wow...that's a lot of information to take in. Let me think... We started with apples, carrots and bananas. I've given him a bit of yogurt too. As for the nappies, yes, he's still wetting about 4 to 5 of them in a day. And he does seem his usual cheeky self in between the nappy changes...

About the rash... well, it's mostly red and raw looking, but there are a few small white spots around it. Can't really see any raised bumps though. But if it could be a yeast infection, should we see a doctor?

The white spots around the rash strongly suggest a secondary yeast (candida) infection, which is common after prolonged diarrhea. This needs antifungal cream like clotrimazole or miconazole—available over-the-counter at pharmacies, or your GP can prescribe it. Apply it with each nappy change under the barrier cream until it clears (usually 7-10 days).

**Regarding the diarrhea:** The yogurt is the likely culprit if it's cow's milk-based. At 6 months with recent dairy introduction and this pattern of watery green stools, a temporary cow's milk protein sensitivity is very possible. I'd suggest **stopping all dairy (yogurt, cheese, any milk in cooking) for 2 weeks** and see if the stools improve. Continue breastfeeding and the other solids you mentioned.

**Your plan:**
1. Get antifungal cream for the rash today
2. Eliminate dairy temporarily
3. Continue frequent nappy changes and barrier cream
4. Monitor hydration (4+ wet nappies daily)

**Seek urgent care if:** he becomes lethargic, refuses feeds, has fewer than 3 wet nappies in 24 hours, develops a fever, or you see blood in the stool. Otherwise, the diarrhea should improve within a few days of stopping dairy. Does this make sense?

Yes, got it. I'll stop the yogurt and pick up the antifungal cream. I didn't realise dairy could cause such a reaction! I'll keep a close eye on his hydration and stool changes. Should I reintroduce dairy after 2 weeks or wait a bit longer? And when should I worry about the rash not clearing up? Thanks for your help!

After 2 weeks, if the diarrhea has completely resolved, you can try reintroducing dairy—but start with small amounts of well-cooked dairy (like cheese in cooking) rather than straight yogurt or milk, and watch for symptoms returning over 3-5 days. If symptoms recur, avoid dairy until 9-12 months and discuss with your GP.

The rash should start improving within 3-4 days of using the antifungal cream. If it's not noticeably better by day 5, or if it worsens/spreads despite treatment, see your GP—it may need a stronger prescription antifungal or there could be bacterial superinfection.

**One final check:** Has he had any vomiting, or is it purely the diarrhea? And just to confirm—no blood or black colour in the stools, correct?

You're doing all the right things. Keep up the frequent changes and barrier cream, and he should turn the corner soon.

Hello, My husband is taking Oxycodone due to a broken leg/surgery. He has been taking this pain medication for one month. We are trying to conceive our second baby. Will this medication afect the fetus? Or the health of the baby? Or can it bring birth defects? Thank you.

Thank you for reaching out with this important question. Oxycodone doesn't directly affect sperm quality or cause birth defects in the baby—the main concern with opioids and pregnancy is maternal use during pregnancy, not paternal use before conception. However, prolonged opioid use (even for legitimate pain) can temporarily reduce testosterone and sperm production in some men, which might affect fertility but not the health of a future baby.

A few clarifying questions:

1. How much longer does his doctor expect him to need the oxycodone—is he tapering off soon, or is this expected to continue for several more weeks?

2. Has he noticed any other side effects like fatigue, mood changes, or decreased libido?

3. Are there any other medications or health conditions I should know about for either of you?

Thank you for your response, it's a relief to know that Oxycodone doesn't directly affect sperm quality or cause birth defects. As for your questions, his doctor expects him to be on the medication for at least another two weeks. He hasn't complained about any side effects like fatigue, mood changes, or decreased libido. Actually, he's been eager for us to get back to trying to conceive. As for other medications, he's just on a multivitamin. Aside from my husband's broken leg, we're both generally in good health.

That's reassuring—two more weeks is a reasonable timeframe, and if he's feeling well otherwise, the oxycodone is unlikely to pose any significant barrier to conception or fetal health. Once he's off the medication and his pain is better controlled, his hormone levels and sperm production (if affected at all) should normalize within a few weeks to a couple of months.

**My recommendation:** You can start trying to conceive now if you wish, but waiting 4–6 weeks after he stops the oxycodone may optimize his fertility and give his body time to fully recover from both the medication and the stress of surgery. There's no evidence this medication in the father causes birth defects, so the timing is more about maximizing your chances of conception than safety concerns for the baby.

One last question: Are you currently taking prenatal vitamins with folic acid (ideally 400–800 mcg daily)? This is important to start before conception to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.

Yes, I'm taking a prenatal vitamin daily that contains folic acid. Your advice about waiting 4-6 weeks after he stops the medication makes sense to me, we'll consider that. It's a huge relief to know that the Oxycodone won't bring risk to our baby. Thank you so much for your help.

You're very welcome—I'm glad I could help ease your concerns. You're doing all the right things by taking prenatal vitamins and planning thoughtfully. Best wishes to both of you for a smooth recovery for your husband and success when you're ready to expand your family. If any new questions come up or if his recovery changes, don't hesitate to reach out.
Thank you so much, really appreciate your help. It's nice to have such clear guidance during this confusing time. I will surely reach out if any new questions arise.
You're very welcome—I'm here if you need anything. Wishing you both all the best with his recovery and your growing family. Take care!

lump under left nipple and stomach pain (male) Hi,I have recently noticed a few weeks ago a lump under my nipple, it hurts to touch and is about the size of a quarter. Also I have bern experiencing stomach pains that prevent me from eating. I immediatly feel full and have extreme pain. Please help

I understand your concern about the lump and stomach pain. The tender lump under your nipple could be gynecomastia (breast tissue growth) or a cyst, while the stomach pain with early fullness needs evaluation to rule out ulcer, gastritis, or other causes.

A few important questions:

**How old are you, and have you started any new medications, supplements, or steroids recently?** Some medications can cause breast tissue changes.

**With the stomach pain—is it burning, sharp, or cramping? Does it happen before or after meals, and have you had any vomiting, black stools, or unintentional weight loss?**

**Any fever, nipple discharge, skin changes over the lump, or testicular pain/swelling?**

I'm 45 years old and I haven't started any new medications or supplements. As for the stomach pain, it's more of a sharp feeling and usually happens after meals. No vomiting or black stools, but I have been losing some weight unintentionally.

There's no fever, nipple discharge or skin changes, and thankfully, no testicular pain or swelling. That lump though...it's really starting to worry me.

The unintentional weight loss combined with sharp pain after eating and early fullness raises concern for a gastric or upper GI issue that needs prompt evaluation—possibilities include peptic ulcer, gastritis, or less commonly something more serious. The breast lump in a 45-year-old man also warrants assessment, though gynecomastia is common and often benign.

How much weight have you lost and over what time period? Any difficulty swallowing, persistent nausea, or pain that radiates to your back?

Does anything make the stomach pain better or worse—like antacids, certain foods, or lying down?

Do you smoke, drink alcohol regularly, or have any history of stomach problems, liver issues, or family history of cancer?

Well, I think I've lost around 10 pounds over the last two months or so. And yes, the pain does get worse when I lie down, that's why I've been having trouble sleeping lately. I haven't noticed any difficulty swallowing or persistent nausea though.

As for smoking and drinking, I do have a couple of beers on the weekends, but I quit smoking about a year ago. No history of stomach problems or liver issues in my family that I know of. But, my grandfather had colon cancer, if that's relevant?

Ten pounds in two months with pain worse when lying down and early fullness is significant—this pattern can suggest a gastric ulcer, severe gastritis, or potentially a mass. Your grandfather's colon cancer is noted, though your symptoms point more to the upper GI tract.

**You need to see a doctor in person within the next few days—ideally your primary care physician or a gastroenterologist.** You'll likely need an upper endoscopy (scope) to directly visualize your stomach and rule out ulcers, H. pylori infection, or other causes. Blood work and possibly imaging may also be ordered. The breast lump should be examined at the same visit.

**In the meantime:** avoid NSAIDs like ibuprofen (they worsen ulcers), eat smaller frequent meals, elevate your head when sleeping, and avoid alcohol. **Seek emergency care immediately if you develop vomiting blood, black tarry stools, severe unrelenting pain, or dizziness/fainting.**

Have you been taking any over-the-counter pain relievers regularly, and can you get an appointment with your doctor this week?

I've been taking some ibuprofen for the pain actually, didn't know it could make things worse. I'll stop that right away. And yeah, I can try and get an appointment with my doctor this week. I'm pretty anxious about all this, but I guess it's better to know what's going on.

Good—stopping the ibuprofen is important, as it can definitely worsen stomach ulcers and bleeding risk. Your anxiety is completely understandable, but getting evaluated quickly is the right move and will help clarify what's happening.

**For pain relief while you wait, you can try acetaminophen (Tylenol) instead—it's safer for your stomach.** Over-the-counter antacids like Tums or an H2-blocker like famotidine (Pepcid) may also provide some temporary relief.

**Make that appointment as soon as possible—mention the weight loss and pain pattern so they prioritize you.** If you can't get in within a few days, consider urgent care or a GI specialist directly. Both the stomach symptoms and the breast lump need hands-on examination and likely testing.

**Remember: go to the ER right away if you have any bleeding signs, severe pain, or feel faint.** Do you have a primary care doctor you can call tomorrow morning?

I have a 5 month old baby who is very congested with a terrible cough. Its rattly/raspy and croupy sounding cough. She started choking on her coughs and the mucous that has come up. She also has a fever and runny nose. Should i take her to urgent care?

Given your baby's age (5 months), fever, and especially the choking episodes with mucus, I recommend taking her to urgent care or the emergency department now. Infants this young can deteriorate quickly with respiratory infections, and the choking spells are concerning.

Before you go, I need to know: Is she having any trouble breathing between coughs (like fast breathing, chest pulling in with breaths, or flaring nostrils)? Is she feeding normally and staying hydrated with wet diapers? What's her fever temperature?

While you prepare to go, keep her upright and use a bulb suction to gently clear her nose if needed.

She's been breathing pretty fast and her nostrils do seem to flare a bit. Her chest seems to go in when she breathes, now that you mention it. I've been feeding her, but she doesn't seem to be eating as much or as often as usual. Her fever was 100.4°F last I checked. I'll start getting ready to take her to the hospital. I'm really scared, is there anything else I can do to help her while we're on the way?

You're doing the right thing by going now—those signs (fast breathing, nostril flaring, chest retractions, reduced feeding) indicate she's working hard to breathe and needs immediate evaluation. This is urgent.

While traveling, keep her upright in her car seat, stay calm, and don't give any medications unless instructed by emergency staff. If her lips or face turn blue, she stops breathing, or becomes unresponsive, pull over and call 911 immediately.

Go straight to the ER—don't delay. She needs oxygen monitoring and possibly breathing treatments or other support that only the hospital can provide.

Okay, I understand. I will keep her upright in her car seat and will certainly not delay. I'll be looking out for any changes in her color or responsiveness. It's just so hard to see her like this. I'm leaving for the ER now. Thank you for your help.

You're being a great parent by acting quickly. I know it's frightening, but the ER team will take excellent care of her—respiratory distress in infants is something they handle routinely and effectively.

Drive safely, and know that getting her evaluated now is exactly what she needs. Once she's stabilized, they'll determine the cause (likely bronchiolitis or another viral infection) and provide the right treatment. You've got this—stay as calm as you can for her. Wishing you both the best.
Thank you for the reassurances. It's really tough seeing her struggle, but I know we're doing the right thing. I'll do my best to stay calm. We're on our way to the ER now.

You're handling this exactly right. The ER staff will assess her breathing, oxygen levels, and hydration status right away, and they have the tools to help her feel better quickly.

Once you arrive, let them know about the choking episodes, the retractions, and how long she's had the fever—that will help them prioritize her care. Safe travels, and take care of yourself too.

I am F 38 in good shape work out (do triathlons) regular but have had back pain from different reasons throughout my life now I every so often wake up with severe lower back, hip pain for no reason. today the pain is almost taking my breathe away when i move. It is a dull pain when i am just lying down but the moment I make any sort of movement I have sharp and sometimes shooting pain down my legs.

That sounds quite painful, especially with the shooting pain down your legs. I need to understand this better to help you safely.

Which leg or legs does the pain shoot down, and does it go below the knee? Any numbness, tingling, or weakness in your legs or feet? Also, any loss of bowel or bladder control, or numbness in your groin/inner thigh area?

The pain typically shoots down both legs, but I've noticed it's more severe in my right leg. The pain doesn't go below my knee, and I haven't felt any numbness or tingling. As for weakness, it's hard to say, because when the pain is really intense, I just avoid moving. I haven't had any loss of bowel or bladder control and no numbness in my groin or inner thigh area. I hope that helps.

Good news that there's no numbness in the saddle area or bowel/bladder issues—those would be red flags needing immediate ER evaluation.

When did this episode start, and have you had any recent falls, heavy lifting, or new training intensity? Does changing position (like lying on your side with knees bent) help at all, or does coughing/sneezing make it worse?

This episode started about three days ago. I haven't had any falls or been lifting heavy things recently, but I have been training harder for an upcoming triathlon. Changing positions does provide a little bit of relief, but it's temporary. I haven't really noticed if coughing or sneezing make it worse, but I'll pay attention to that.

Three days is significant—acute severe back pain with bilateral leg symptoms after ramping up training suggests possible disc irritation or severe muscle/ligamentary strain, though the bilateral shooting pattern is a bit atypical for a single-level disc issue.

Have you tried any medications (ibuprofen, acetaminophen) or ice/heat, and if so, did they help at all? Any fever, unexplained weight loss, or history of cancer or osteoporosis? Given the severity taking your breath away, are you able to stand and walk short distances, or is the pain completely limiting that?

I've been taking ibuprofen and it helps a little bit, but not much. I've also tried ice, which does provide some relief. As for your other questions, no fever or unexplained weight loss. No history of cancer either, but osteoporosis does run in my family, so that's a concern. I can stand and walk a bit, but it's very painful to do so. The pain is really limiting my movement overall. Getting out of bed in the morning is a struggle.

Given three days of severe pain limiting your function despite ibuprofen, you need a more structured approach. The bilateral shooting pain (especially right-sided, stopping above the knee) plus your training increase points toward lumbar disc irritation or facet joint inflammation, though severe muscle spasm can also cause referred leg pain.

**Plan:**
1. **See a provider today or tomorrow**—either your primary care, urgent care, or a spine specialist—for exam and possibly imaging (X-ray or MRI) to rule out disc herniation or other structural issues.
2. **Medication upgrade**: Ask about a short course of a muscle relaxant (like cyclobenzaprine) or a stronger anti-inflammatory; continue ibuprofen 400–600 mg every 6–8 hours with food if tolerated.
3. **Relative rest**: Avoid triathlon training and heavy bending/twisting for now; gentle walking as tolerated is okay.
4. **Ice 15–20 min every 2–3 hours** for the first few days, then try alternating with heat.
5. **Physical therapy referral** once acute pain settles—core stability is key for athletes.

**Red flags—go to ER if:** new numbness in groin/buttocks, loss of bowel/bladder control, progressive leg weakness, or pain becomes unbearable. Does this plan make sense, and do you have a provider you can contact today?

sir, MY uncle has ILD-Interstitial Lung disease.from my research over google i found that the cause is important to be known. the cause wat i feel is due to breakage of acid bottle in bathroom which caused lot of smoke and that time he wasnot able to be normal for 15-20 minutes. then he was normal .may be that would have been the reason for this ILD. Please suggest wat we should do

I understand your concern about your uncle's ILD diagnosis. A single acute inhalation exposure (like acid fumes) can cause immediate airway injury, but typical ILD usually develops from chronic exposures, autoimmune conditions, medications, or other causes—so the acid incident may not be the primary trigger, though it's worth mentioning to his pulmonologist.

**To help guide next steps, I need a few details:**

1. When was he diagnosed with ILD, and what type did the doctor specify (if any—like idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, etc.)?

2. What symptoms is he experiencing now (shortness of breath, cough, how severe), and is he already seeing a lung specialist?

3. Does he have any known autoimmune diseases, long-term medication use, or occupational exposures (farming, birds, mold, dusts)?

Oh, I see. To answer your questions, he got diagnosed with ILD last month but the doctor didn't specify what type it was. He's been having a persistent cough and gets out of breath quickly, and it's been progressively getting worse. He isn't currently under the care of a lung specialist. As for any autoimmune diseases or long-term medication use, none that we know of. He worked in construction for years, so I guess he's been exposed to a lot of dusts.

Given his construction work history (chronic dust exposure) and progressive symptoms, that's a much more likely cause of his ILD than the single acid incident. **He needs to see a pulmonologist urgently**—ILD can worsen without proper treatment, and some types respond well to early intervention.

**What you should do now:**

1. **Get a pulmonology referral immediately** (through his primary doctor or directly if possible)—the specialist will likely order high-resolution CT chest imaging and possibly pulmonary function tests if not done already.
2. **Bring all records** from the ILD diagnosis, including any chest X-rays or CT scans.
3. **Document his work history** in detail (years in construction, specific exposures like silica, asbestos, concrete dust).
4. If his breathing worsens significantly, he has chest pain, or his lips/fingernails turn blue, go to the ER.

**One clarification:** Is he currently on any treatment (oxygen, steroids, inhalers), and does he have the actual diagnostic reports or imaging you can share with the pulmonologist?

Thanks doctor for the detailed instructions. As for the treatment, the doctor did prescribe an inhaler for his cough and shortness of breath, but no oxygen or steroids. I'll look for the reports and images, he must have kept them somewhere. I will surely arrange an appointment with a pulmonologist as soon as possible and get everything ready. I'm just worried for my uncle, hope we're not too late for the treatment.

Your concern is completely understandable, but seeking specialist care now is exactly the right move—many ILD patients do well with proper management, especially when caught relatively early. The fact that he was diagnosed just last month and you're acting on it promptly is good.

**While waiting for the pulmonologist appointment:**

1. **Avoid further lung irritants**—no smoking (if applicable), minimize dust exposure, use masks if he's still around construction sites.
2. **Monitor his symptoms closely**—if he develops fever, sudden worsening of breathlessness at rest, confusion, or bluish discoloration of lips/nails, seek emergency care immediately.
3. **Prepare a timeline** for the pulmonologist: when symptoms started, how they've progressed, detailed work history (which materials/dusts, how many years), and bring those diagnostic reports/imaging.

The pulmonologist will likely repeat or refine testing to classify the specific ILD type, which guides treatment—some respond to anti-fibrotic drugs, others to immunosuppression, and supportive care helps regardless. You're doing the right things for your uncle.

Thank you so much for your advice, doctor. It's comforting to know we're doing the right thing by seeking specialist care quickly. We'll make sure to follow your instructions closely—avoiding further lung irritants and monitoring his symptoms. Also, I'll start preparing the timeline for the pulmonologist. I really hope the treatment works well for him. We're just trying to do our best to help him through this.

You're clearly being a great advocate for your uncle, and that support matters enormously. One last important point: **ask the pulmonologist specifically about occupational lung disease screening**—given his construction history, conditions like silicosis or asbestosis may be relevant, and some have legal/compensation implications that require specific documentation.

In the meantime, encourage him to stay as active as his breathing allows (gentle walking helps maintain conditioning), stay hydrated, and keep using the inhaler as prescribed. If you can't get a pulmonology appointment within 2–3 weeks, push harder or ask his primary doctor to expedite it given the progressive symptoms.

Wishing your uncle the best with his care—you're on the right track.

my husband was working on a project in the house and all of a sudden a bump about the size of a half dollar appeard on his left leg inside below the knee. He is 69 years old and had triple by pass surgery 7 years ago. It stung when it first happened. Doesn t hurt now. He is seated with his leg ellevated. Is this an emergency?

Thank you for reaching out. A sudden bump that size with initial stinging could be an insect bite/sting, a ruptured Baker's cyst, or less commonly a vascular issue like a blood clot or localized bleeding, especially given his cardiac history.

**Key questions:**
1. Is the area red, warm, or tender to touch? Any bruising or discoloration?
2. Does he have swelling, pain, or warmth elsewhere in that leg (calf, thigh)?
3. Is he on blood thinners like aspirin, Plavix, warfarin, or other anticoagulants?

**If** he develops increasing pain, significant leg swelling, shortness of breath, chest pain, or the bump rapidly enlarges, go to the ER immediately—these could signal a clot or bleeding needing urgent evaluation.

Thank you for your assistance, doctor. The area around the bump is not red or warm. No sign of any bruising or discoloration either. As for the rest of the leg, it seems normal, no different from the other one. He is on aspirin, though. Is that a problem?

Good to know the area looks normal and the rest of the leg is unaffected—that's reassuring. Aspirin does increase bleeding risk slightly, but a spontaneous bleed large enough to cause a half-dollar bump without trauma is less likely.

**A few more details:**
1. Was he kneeling, leaning against something, or did anything bump/press that spot right before the bump appeared?
2. Is the bump firm or soft? Does it feel like fluid under the skin or more solid?
3. Any history of varicose veins, prior blood clots, or leg swelling issues?

If it was truly spontaneous with no contact or injury, and especially if it changes in size, becomes painful, or he develops systemic symptoms (fever, feeling unwell), he should be seen today or tomorrow for evaluation.

Actually, he was kneeling while working, so there was some pressure on that spot. The bump feels sort of firm, but not too hard. I'm not sure if it feels like fluid or not. He does have a history of varicose veins, but no prior blood clots or swelling. Can we wait to see if it changes overnight or is it something that needs to be checked now? We're both quite worried.

That context helps a lot—kneeling pressure plus varicose veins makes a traumatic cause (like a ruptured small varicose vein or localized bleeding into the tissue) much more likely than something sinister. The aspirin may have allowed a bit more bleeding from the minor trauma.

**Plan:**
1. Continue elevation and apply a cold compress for 15–20 minutes every few hours today to reduce swelling.
2. Monitor closely: if the bump shrinks or stays stable over the next 12–24 hours and he has no new symptoms, it's likely resolving on its own.
3. Seek care today if the bump rapidly enlarges, becomes very painful, the leg swells significantly, or he develops fever, warmth, or redness—these would suggest infection or a more significant bleed.
4. If it's unchanged or only slowly improving by tomorrow, a same-day or next-day visit with his primary doctor or urgent care is reasonable for a physical exam and possibly an ultrasound to rule out anything vascular.

**Red flags needing ER:** sudden severe leg pain, entire leg swelling, shortness of breath, or chest pain. Otherwise, close observation tonight is safe.

Oh, that makes sense. He was putting a lot of pressure on his knee while working. We'll definitely follow your advice and keep a close watch on it. The cold compress sounds like a good idea. And thank you for letting us know when it would be necessary to go to the ER. That really helps alleviate some of this worry.

You're very welcome—I'm glad that helps ease your concern. Given the kneeling and his varicose veins, this really does sound like minor trauma with some bleeding under the skin, which should settle down with rest and ice.

Just keep that leg elevated when he's sitting, avoid kneeling or pressure on that spot for the next few days, and watch for those red flags. If you have any doubts or it doesn't start improving by tomorrow, don't hesitate to have him seen. Wishing him a smooth recovery!

hi my nine year old son had a cough and flu symptons three months ago and the chesty sounding cough and green phlegm still remains. it did seem to get better but never totally went and has now picked up again...he has only ever had antibiotics once in his live which suggests he his generally fitand well and active...never short of breath or weezy...so why would this be....

A persistent productive cough with green phlegm for three months after an initial viral illness raises concern for a secondary bacterial infection (like prolonged bronchitis or even pertussis) or post-infectious airway inflammation that hasn't fully resolved.

**Three key questions:**

1. Does he have any fever now, or did he spike fevers again when the cough picked back up?

2. Is the cough worse at night, or does anything specific trigger it (exercise, cold air, lying down)?

3. Any history of asthma, eczema, or allergies in him or the family?

Given the three-month duration and recent worsening, I'd recommend seeing his pediatrician soon for a chest exam and possibly a chest X-ray to rule out pneumonia or other complications. If he develops high fever, difficulty breathing, chest pain, or looks unwell, seek same-day evaluation.

He's mostly indoors because of the current situation. And, no, there's no history of asthma, eczema, or allergies in our family. Does this mean he needs to get an X-ray? I'm a bit worried about exposing him to that.

The lack of fever and no family history of asthma is reassuring, but the nighttime worsening and three-month duration still warrant investigation. A chest X-ray uses very low radiation (similar to a few days of natural background exposure) and is quite safe—it's important to rule out lingering pneumonia or other structural issues that could explain why this isn't clearing.

**Two more questions:**

1. When he coughs up the green phlegm, is it happening multiple times every day, or just occasionally in the morning?

2. Does he have any nasal congestion, post-nasal drip, or throat clearing during the day?

The nighttime cough can point to post-nasal drip or reactive airway inflammation. I'd still recommend an in-person exam soon—his doctor can listen to his lungs and decide if an X-ray is truly needed or if a trial of treatment (like an inhaler or a course of antibiotics) makes sense first.

Thanks for explaining about the X-ray... that makes me feel a bit more at ease.

Good—frequent green phlegm production and throat clearing with nose-blowing strongly suggest **post-nasal drip** (possibly from prolonged sinusitis) feeding into his airways, which can perpetuate a wet cough and even cause secondary bacterial bronchitis.

**Summary:** Most likely a combination of post-nasal drip and prolonged bronchitis. Less likely but worth excluding: atypical infection (like pertussis or mycoplasma) or early bronchiectasis if this drags on.

**Plan:**
1. **See his pediatrician this week** for a chest and sinus exam.
2. They may prescribe antibiotics (to cover sinusitis and bronchitis) and possibly a nasal steroid spray or saline rinses.
3. If no improvement in 10–14 days on treatment, or if symptoms worsen, push for that chest X-ray.
4. Encourage fluids, humidified air at night, and elevating his head slightly when sleeping.

**Red flags—seek same-day care if:** high fever, fast/difficult breathing, chest pain, blood in phlegm, or he looks significantly unwell. Otherwise, he should start improving within a week or two of the right treatment.

Okay, that makes sense. I didn't realize that post-nasal drip could lead to a cough like this. I'll definitely get him in to see his pediatrician this week and we'll start using a humidifier at night. I'll also make sure to keep an eye out for those red flags you mentioned. Thank you for all your help, I appreciate it.

You're very welcome—you're doing the right thing by getting him checked. The humidifier and head elevation should help with comfort in the meantime. One last tip: if the pediatrician prescribes antibiotics, make sure he finishes the full course even if he starts feeling better halfway through, so the infection clears completely. Wishing him a speedy recovery—don't hesitate to follow up if anything changes or new symptoms pop up!

Given your recurrent symptoms, thick discharge, and the pattern you're describing, I'm most concerned about:

2. **Persistent or recurrent bacterial vaginosis**

I'm sorry you're dealing with such severe pain, Wendy. Given your cancer history and the pattern you're describing—lower back pain radiating to the groin and down the thigh—this needs careful evaluation. The possibilities range from nerve compression (like from a herniated disc or spinal stenosis) to cancer-related causes such as bone metastases or nerve involvement, to other issues like kidney stones or hip problems.

A few important questions:

1. What type of cancer are you being treated for, and are you currently on active treatment?

2. Is the pain worse with certain movements (bending, walking, lying down), or is it constant regardless of position?

To be honest, standing on my toes and heels is quite difficult with the pain and weakness. And when I press on my lower back area, it hurts quite a bit more. **Your plan:**
1. Call your oncologist now; if you can't reach them or it's after hours, go to the ER—explain you're on chemo for breast cancer with new severe back pain, leg weakness, and concern for spinal metastases.
2. You'll likely need urgent MRI and possibly adjustment of your cancer treatment based on findings.
3. In the meantime, avoid heavy lifting or twisting movements.

**Go to the ER immediately if:** your leg becomes unable to bear weight, you develop saddle numbness (numbness between your legs/buttocks), or any bladder/bowel control issues—these indicate spinal cord compression requiring emergency treatment within hours.

Oh my, this is overwhelming but I understand. I'm going to call my oncology team right away and if I can't reach them, I'll head to the ER. Thank you for your guidance. I'll avoid any heavy lifting or twisting until I can get this sorted. I just hope it's nothing too serious...

I understand this is frightening, but you're taking exactly the right steps. The good news is that even if this turns out to be metastatic disease, there are effective treatments—radiation can often relieve bone pain quickly, and your oncology team has many options to address spread.

hye, My aunt is having shortness of breath and she is on vent now. Her breast showed some kind of infection that apparently turned out to have black blisters. I could she those spreading. When we went for lungs x-ray doctor said she has accumulation of water in her lungs

I'm very concerned about your aunt's condition - black blisters spreading on the breast combined with respiratory failure requiring ventilation and fluid in the lungs suggests a serious, potentially life-threatening infection. This needs immediate intensive care management if she's not already in an ICU.

To help me understand the situation better:

1. How long ago did the breast infection start, and how quickly did the black blisters appear and spread?

2. Has she been diagnosed with any specific infection (like necrotizing fasciitis, gas gangrene, or sepsis), and is she currently in an ICU receiving antibiotics and surgical evaluation?

3. Does she have diabetes, cancer, or any condition affecting her immune system?

Well, her infection started about a week ago. It wasn't until a few days ago we noticed the black blisters. They seemed to be spreading pretty fast. The doctors haven't mentioned any specific infections, but they put her in ICU yesterday. And no, she doesn't have diabetes or cancer. She's always been healthy, this just came outta nowhere.

This sounds like necrotizing soft tissue infection (possibly necrotizing fasciitis or gas gangrene) - a surgical emergency where tissue dies rapidly. The black blisters indicate dead tissue, and the lung fluid with respiratory failure suggests septic shock from overwhelming infection spreading through her bloodstream.

The most critical question: **Has a surgeon evaluated her breast, and has she had or is she scheduled for emergency surgery to remove the dead/infected tissue?** This is lifesaving and must happen urgently - antibiotics alone won't work if dead tissue isn't removed.

Two other important points:
- Is she on strong IV antibiotics (usually multiple types)?
- Has anyone mentioned checking for Group A Strep, Clostridium, or other aggressive bacteria?

If surgeons haven't been involved yet, her family should immediately ask the ICU team about surgical consultation - hours matter with this type of infection.

Yes, she is on some kind of strong antibiotics via IV, but I'm not sure about the group A Strep or Clostridium check. The doctors did mention something about surgery, but they didn't go into specifics. It's all been really overwhelming. And will she be okay after the surgery? I'm really worried for her.

I understand how frightening this is. Her prognosis depends on how quickly they remove all the dead tissue and control the infection - necrotizing infections are very serious, but survival improves significantly with aggressive early surgery plus ICU support. The fact that she's already in ICU on antibiotics and surgery is being discussed is important.

**What you and your family should do now:**

1. **Confirm surgery is happening urgently** (ideally within hours, not days) - ask the ICU team directly: "When is the surgeon operating to remove the infected tissue?" This is the most critical intervention.

2. **Ask if cultures were sent** to identify the exact bacteria so antibiotics can be optimized.

3. **Prepare for possible multiple surgeries** - these infections often require going back to remove more tissue as doctors see what's viable.

4. **Watch for updates on her organ function** - kidneys, blood pressure, oxygen levels - since sepsis affects the whole body.

**Red flags to report immediately:** worsening confusion, dropping blood pressure, decreased urine output, or blisters spreading to new areas.

Is the surgical team planning to operate today or tomorrow, and has anyone explained what they'll need to remove?

They mentioned they were planning to operate tomorrow morning. They didn't really explain in detail what they would need to remove, everything just feels like it's moving so fast. We've been so caught up in her condition, it's been hard to grasp everything.

Tomorrow morning may be appropriate timing, but given the rapid spread you described, I'd encourage your family to ask the surgical team directly: "Given how fast this is spreading, does it need to happen sooner than tomorrow morning?" Sometimes these infections require more urgent intervention.

The surgery will likely remove all visibly dead/infected breast tissue and possibly surrounding tissue to ensure they get ahead of the infection - this may be disfiguring but is lifesaving. She'll likely need additional surgeries over the next few days to reassess and remove any newly affected tissue.

**Critical for tonight:** Make sure the ICU team knows the black areas were spreading quickly over just a few days. If you notice ANY new black areas, spreading redness beyond what's already there, or if she becomes more unstable (blood pressure dropping, less responsive), tell the nurses immediately - this could warrant moving surgery up.

Has her family designated someone as the main contact person to receive updates and ask questions of the medical team? It helps to have one person coordinating communication so nothing gets missed in this overwhelming time.

i am 28 yrs old, i got married before 6 year, i was infected by pulmonary tuberculosis before 6 years, i took treatment for 6 months after that i statred gainig weigt, my periods was irredulat, i increased nearlt 20 kgs after that, now my weight is 75 kgs, i trying to conceive, i took tsh, other blood test too, but everything is normal, do i have the chances to conceive

I understand your concern about conceiving after your TB treatment and weight gain. A few important questions:

1. **How irregular are your periods now?** (For example, do they come every 35–40 days, or do you skip months entirely?)

2. **Which specific blood tests were done recently?** (TSH alone, or did they also check FSH, LH, prolactin, or AMH? Any ultrasound of your ovaries?)

3. **Has your husband had a semen analysis?**

The good news is that completing TB treatment and having normal TSH are positive signs. Weight gain and irregular periods often point to conditions like PCOS, which is very treatable for fertility. I need these details to give you the most helpful guidance.

Thank you for your understanding, doctor. My periods are a bit all over the place, I think there's more like 40-45 days between them sometimes, but I have skipped a month entirely a couple of times too. As for the blood tests, I am not sure about the specifics. I remember the tsh because there was a lot of discussion about that. And no, my husband hasn't had a semen analysis. Should he be getting one?

Yes, a semen analysis is essential—about one-third of fertility issues involve male factors, so it's a simple first step that shouldn't be skipped.

Your cycle pattern (40–45 days, occasional skipped months) plus the significant weight gain strongly suggest **PCOS (polycystic ovary syndrome)**, which is very common and treatable. I recommend:

1. **Get a pelvic ultrasound** to look at your ovaries
2. **Repeat bloodwork on day 2–3 of your cycle**: LH, FSH, prolactin, testosterone, and fasting insulin/glucose
3. **Your husband gets a semen analysis** before any further female testing

One more question: **Do you have excess facial/body hair, acne, or darkening of skin in body folds?** These help confirm PCOS. With the right treatment (often starting with lifestyle changes and ovulation-inducing medications), your chances of conceiving are very good.

Oh, I do have some excess hair on my chin and upper lip, but I thought that was just because of my genes. I do have some acne, but I had that even before the weight gain. Darkening of skin, I am not so sure... should I be worried? And thank you for the advice regarding the tests, I'll discuss with my husband about the semen analysis and will schedule the other tests and ultrasound for me.

The excess hair and acne fit perfectly with PCOS—no need to worry, it's very manageable. Darkening in areas like the neck, armpits, or groin (called acanthosis nigricans) can signal insulin resistance, which is common with PCOS and important to address for both fertility and long-term health.

**Your plan:**
1. Schedule the pelvic ultrasound and day 2–3 bloodwork (LH, FSH, prolactin, testosterone, fasting insulin/glucose)
2. Your husband gets semen analysis
3. Start working on gradual weight loss (even 5–10% helps restore ovulation)—focus on lower refined carbs, regular meals, and 30 minutes of activity most days

Once you have those results, treatment typically starts with ovulation induction (like letrozole or clomiphene), and possibly metformin if insulin resistance is confirmed. **Your chances of conceiving are genuinely good with proper treatment.** Bring all results to a gynecologist or fertility specialist to create a tailored plan. Any other symptoms or concerns I should know about?

Oh wow, I didn't realize that those things could be connected. I will definitely talk to my husband about the semen analysis and get those tests scheduled. We really want a baby so I'm willing to do whatever it takes. And I will try to make some lifestyle changes as well. In terms of other symptoms, I do find myself feeling tired most of the time, and I feel like my mood swings a lot. But I'm not sure if that's related or if it's just stress.

Fatigue and mood swings are very common with PCOS and insulin resistance—they're not just stress. Improving insulin sensitivity (through diet, exercise, and possibly metformin) often helps energy and mood significantly.

**Two final questions:**

1. **Any history of sleep issues or snoring?** (Weight gain and PCOS can contribute to sleep apnea, which worsens fatigue and fertility.)

2. **Are you taking any vitamins or supplements currently?** (I'd recommend starting folic acid 400–800 mcg daily now, before conception.)

You're on exactly the right track. Once you have the test results, a fertility specialist can fine-tune your treatment. With PCOS management and your husband's semen analysis, most couples in your situation conceive within 6–12 months of starting treatment. Stay positive—you're taking all the right steps.

Please see a doctor today or tomorrow—urgent care or your primary care can order foot X-rays. Until then, stay off it as much as possible, keep it elevated above heart level when sitting or lying down, and you can use ice for 15-20 minutes at a time if it helps with pain.

Your worry is understandable, but getting the X-ray is the right move—it will guide proper treatment and help you heal correctly. The fact that sensation returns with movement is reassuring, and no fever or spreading redness makes infection less likely.

Most foot fractures, even if present, heal well with appropriate immobilization (boot or cast) and protected weight-bearing. The key is catching it now rather than walking on an undiagnosed fracture, which could delay healing or cause complications.

Keep elevating and icing until you're seen. Either way, you should see improvement within 1-2 weeks of proper treatment. Wishing you a smooth visit and recovery—don't hesitate to follow up if anything changes before you're seen.

hi, i have been recently diagnosed with H pylori.. i have been give the triple treatment of calithramycin, amoxxicilin and omeprazole.. is dis something very serious and does this have some long term implications etc.can u plz give some detailed information about Hpylori. thnx

I understand your concern—H. pylori is very common (about half the world has it) and the good news is it's curable with the antibiotics you've been prescribed. Most people clear it completely and have no long-term problems once treated.

**What it is:** H. pylori is a bacteria that lives in the stomach lining and can cause ulcers or chronic inflammation (gastritis). If left untreated for many years, it slightly increases the risk of stomach ulcers and, rarely, stomach cancer—but successful treatment eliminates these risks.

**Your treatment:** The triple therapy you're on (clarithromycin, amoxicillin, omeprazole) is highly effective (80-90% cure rate). It's crucial to complete the full course (usually 10-14 days) even if you feel better.

**After treatment:** You'll likely need a test 4+ weeks after finishing antibiotics to confirm eradication (usually a stool antigen or breath test).

A few questions to help you:
1. What symptoms led to your H. pylori testing—stomach pain, nausea, or something else?
2. Are you tolerating the antibiotics okay, or having side effects like diarrhea?
3. How many days into the treatment are you?

I thought it was just because of stress or something, you know. But then the pain started getting worse and that's when I got tested. As for the treatment, I'm on day 6 now. The antibiotics are making me feel a bit nauseous at times, but I've been managing it. Is that normal?

Yes, nausea is a very common side effect—the antibiotics can irritate your stomach and disrupt your gut bacteria temporarily. Taking the medications with food (if you're not already) often helps, and the nausea usually improves once you finish the course.

Since you're on day 6, you're nearly halfway through. Keep pushing—it's really important to complete all 10-14 days to avoid treatment failure and antibiotic resistance.

**Two things to monitor:**
1. If you develop severe diarrhea (especially bloody or watery multiple times daily), severe abdominal pain, or persistent vomiting where you can't keep the pills down, contact your doctor—you may need adjustment.
2. Your stomach pain should gradually improve over the next few weeks as the infection clears and inflammation settles.

A couple of quick questions:
1. Has your stomach pain improved at all since starting treatment, or is it about the same?
2. Are you taking the omeprazole in the morning on an empty stomach (30-60 min before breakfast)? That timing maximizes its effectiveness.

Thanks for the advice, doc. I have been taking the meds with food, yeah. My tummy ache is still there, but I think it's a little less than before. And about the omeprazole, I have been taking it in the morning, but not really on an empty stomach. I usually have a bit of breakfast before taking it. Should I change that?

Yes, definitely adjust that—omeprazole works best when taken 30-60 minutes *before* your first meal of the day on an empty stomach. It needs to be absorbed and active before food triggers acid production. So tomorrow, try taking it right when you wake up, then wait at least 30 minutes before eating. You can take the antibiotics with breakfast as you've been doing.

It's encouraging that your pain is slightly better already—that suggests the treatment is working. The full healing of any inflammation or ulcer takes several weeks, so expect continued gradual improvement even after you finish the antibiotics.

**After you complete the course:** Make sure to follow up with your doctor around 4-6 weeks post-treatment for that confirmation test (stool antigen or breath test). Don't skip this—it's the only way to know the bacteria is truly gone.

One last thing: are you experiencing any other side effects like rash, severe diarrhea, or metallic taste, or is it mainly just the nausea?

Thanks a lot for the tips, doc. I'll make sure to take the omeprazole on an empty stomach from tomorrow. And no, I haven't had any rashes or severe diarrhea. Just a bit of metallic taste, yeah. It's mostly the nausea, though. I will definitely get the confirmation test after the treatment. Thanks again for the help.

You're doing great—metallic taste is also very common with clarithromycin and will disappear once you finish. Sugar-free gum or mints can help mask it in the meantime.

**Your plan moving forward:**
1. **Finish all antibiotics** (even if symptoms fully resolve)
2. **Take omeprazole 30-60 min before breakfast** starting tomorrow
3. **Follow-up test 4-6 weeks after completion** to confirm eradication
4. **Avoid NSAIDs** (ibuprofen, aspirin) during and after treatment if possible—they can irritate healing stomach lining

**Red flags—seek care if you develop:**
- Severe/bloody diarrhea, black tarry stools, or vomiting blood/coffee-ground material
- Severe abdominal pain that's worsening or different from your usual pain
- Signs of allergic reaction (rash, swelling, difficulty breathing)

You're over halfway done and tolerating it well. The nausea and metallic taste are temporary annoyances, but you're on track for a full cure. Once confirmed clear, your long-term outlook is excellent—no ongoing concerns. Good luck finishing the course!

You're addressing this early, which is exactly the right approach. Your numbers suggest metabolic changes that respond well to lifestyle—not advanced liver disease. Stay consistent with follow-up labs, and reach out to your doctor if anything changes before then.

I'm sorry you're dealing with this ongoing pain—it sounds really difficult, especially after already having surgery. The combination of deep pain with sex, bowel and bladder pain, and a new ovarian cyst raises concern for endometriosis or possible adhesion recurrence, though other causes need consideration too.

I understand the worry—let me clarify. Endometriosis isn't life-threatening, but it is a chronic condition where tissue similar to the uterine lining grows outside the uterus, causing inflammation, pain, and sometimes adhesions or cysts. It's manageable with treatment (hormonal therapy, pain management, sometimes surgery), and many women live full, active lives with it. The fact that your pain started *after* adhesion surgery and you have a simple cyst (not the classic "chocolate cyst" of endometriosis) makes me wonder if new adhesions could be the main culprit, possibly involving your bowel or bladder given those specific symptoms.

**Here's what I recommend:**

1. **Call your gynecologist this week** to clarify the cyst follow-up plan and specifically discuss your worsening symptoms—mention the pain with sex, bowel movements, and urination. Ask whether they think endometriosis or recurrent adhesions could explain this, and whether pelvic MRI or referral to an endometriosis specialist is warranted.
2. **Consider starting birth control** (combined pill or IUD)—it can suppress ovarian cysts and help with heavy periods/cramping, and if endometriosis is present, it often reduces symptoms.
3. **Track your symptoms** for 2–4 weeks: note when pain occurs (cycle day, activities), severity (1–10 scale), and bowel/bladder patterns. This helps your doctor see the full picture.
4. **Pelvic floor physical therapy** can sometimes

That's a lot of information to absorb... but it's also somewhat relieving to hear that it's not life-threatening. I'll call my gynecologist this week and ask about the follow-up plan and bring up the pain symptoms. Tracking the symptoms sounds like a good idea, I'll start doing that. As for the birth control, I'm a bit concerned about the side effects. Could they make matters worse? And, what's pelvic floor physical therapy?

Birth control side effects vary by person—some get nausea, mood changes, or spotting initially, but most tolerate it well, and it often *improves* pelvic pain, heavy bleeding, and can prevent new cysts. If one type doesn't work, there are many options (pill, IUD, patch). The key is that untreated, your symptoms may worsen, so the benefits usually outweigh risks. Discuss specific concerns with your gynecologist—they can tailor the choice to you.

**Pelvic floor physical therapy** is specialized PT where a trained therapist works on the muscles, nerves, and connective tissue of your pelvis. They use internal and external techniques to release tight muscles, improve pain with sex and bowel movements, and reduce nerve sensitivity. It's evidence-based for pelvic pain and often helps significantly, especially if adhesions or muscle guarding are involved.

**One more clarifying question**: When you have the sharp right-sided pain during sex, is it only with deep penetration, or does any penetration hurt? And does the pain during urination happen throughout urination or just at the start/end?

**Red flags to watch**: sudden severe pain, fever over 100.4°F, vomiting, dizziness when standing, or heavy vaginal bleeding—go to the ER if any of these occur.

Dear Doctor, We are trying to have a baby and gave it a big try this time but as we are planning to go for an Invitro (ICSI) for the next period, my doctor gave me Primolut Not from day 16 to day 25. I am wondering if this will have a negative impact on my pregnancy if I am pregnant because as explained we gave it a big try this time. Thank you in advance for your response. With my Best Regards; Mme Sue

I understand your concern about taking Primolut N while possibly being pregnant this cycle. First, let me reassure you that if conception occurred before you started the medication on day 16, the very early embryo (first 2 weeks after conception) operates on an "all-or-nothing" principle—meaning major harm is unlikely during implantation.

However, since norethisterone (Primolut N) is generally avoided in confirmed pregnancy, I need to understand your situation better:

1. What cycle day are you currently on, and have you taken all the Primolut N doses as prescribed through day 25?

2. When was the first day of your last menstrual period, and are your cycles usually regular?

3. Did your fertility doctor know you were actively trying to conceive this cycle when prescribing the Primolut N (sometimes it's given specifically to prevent pregnancy before starting IVF)?

Hello Doctor, I really appreciate your response. I'm currently on day 28, and I took all the doses of Primolut N as directed. My last cycle started about 28 days ago, and yes, my cycles are usually regular. As for my fertility doctor, I'm not sure if we made it clear we were trying this cycle. You know, it's just all so overwhelming. We're so eager to become parents.

Since you're on day 28 with regular cycles, you could potentially test for pregnancy now—a home pregnancy test would be accurate at this point. The Primolut N you've already taken is unlikely to have caused harm if you conceived, but it's important to know your status before taking any further doses.

Here's what I recommend:

1. **Take a home pregnancy test tomorrow morning** (first morning urine is most accurate)
2. **Contact your fertility doctor immediately** to inform them you were actively trying this cycle and have now completed the Primolut N course—they need this information to adjust your IVF planning
3. **Do not take any additional Primolut N** until you know whether you're pregnant and have spoken with your doctor

If the test is positive, stop the medication and follow up with your fertility doctor within 1-2 days. If negative and your period doesn't start within a week, retest and contact your doctor.

Are you experiencing any pregnancy symptoms, unusual bleeding, or pelvic pain currently?

Thank you for your clear advice. I'll take a pregnancy test tomorrow morning and contact my fertility doctor. As for symptoms, I've been feeling a bit nauseous lately, with some bloating. Nothing too unusual for me prior to a period, though. I don't have any pain or unusual bleeding. This whole situation is giving me a bit of anxiety, to be honest.

Your symptoms could be either early pregnancy or premenstrual, so the test tomorrow will be very informative. The anxiety you're feeling is completely understandable given the uncertainty and your strong desire to conceive.

The good news is that the medication exposure, if you are pregnant, occurred after implantation would have already happened (around day 21-23), and the doses you took are unlikely to affect an established early pregnancy. Many women have inadvertently taken medications in very early pregnancy without adverse outcomes.

**For tonight:** Try to get some rest—I know that's easier said than done. The test tomorrow will give you clarity, and then you and your fertility doctor can make the best plan going forward, whether that's supporting a possible pregnancy or proceeding with your planned ICSI cycle.

**One important safety point:** If you develop severe abdominal pain, heavy bleeding, dizziness, or shoulder pain before your appointment, go to the emergency department to rule out ectopic pregnancy (though this is unlikely at this stage).

Please update your fertility doctor as soon as you have the test result. Is there anything else worrying you about the situation that we should address?

No, Doctor, I think you've addressed all my concerns for now. It's been a bit of a whirlwind, but your advice has made things a lot clearer. I'll take the test tomorrow and get in touch with my fertility doctor. I just hope it all turns out okay. Thank you for your help and concern.

You're very welcome. You're doing exactly the right things, and I can hear how much this means to you. The waiting is hard, but you'll have an answer very soon.

One last thought: whatever the result tomorrow, you have good options ahead—either supporting an unexpected pregnancy this cycle or moving forward with your planned ICSI, where you'll have excellent medical support throughout. Your proactive approach and regular cycles are positive factors.

Wishing you the very best outcome. Take care of yourself tonight, and don't hesitate to reach out to your fertility team with any questions after you test.

Hello, I am in the middle of a serious anxiety/panic attack as I just became aware that I may have a tetanus infection. I am a senior at Clemson University and to be honest the apartment where I resided in the past four months was extremely unsanitary. One toilet was clogged for nearly two months which I now know could have bred bacterial spores that cause tetanus infections. I cut myself shaving around 1 1/2 months ago. I was out of razors and used a razor that had been sitting in the bathroom with the clogged up toilet I mentioned above. I did clean the razor with rubbing alcohol before use however I had an open wound on my face for a while.. About a week. For about a month now I have been feeling extremely irritable, experiencing lockjaw symptoms, been short of breath, had fevers on and off, heart palpitations, and I have noticed that when I smile my face contorts into what one would call a sardonic smile. Am I going to die? Please let me know your opinion

I understand you're very anxious, but let me reassure you: tetanus from a clogged toilet scenario is extremely unlikely. Tetanus spores live in soil and rusty metal, not bathroom environments, and the incubation period is typically 7–10 days (not 1.5 months). That said, your symptoms—lockjaw, difficulty breathing, facial muscle spasms, and fevers—are concerning and need urgent evaluation, whether or not they're related to tetanus.

**Go to an emergency department now or call 911** if you're having trouble breathing, severe jaw stiffness, or muscle spasms. If symptoms are milder, see a doctor today.

To help me understand better:

1. Can you fully open your mouth and chew normally, or is your jaw actually stuck/stiff?
2. Are the facial muscle changes constant, or only when you smile or make expressions?
3. When did your last tetanus booster shot occur (if you know)?

Thank you for replying so quickly. I'm still really worried though, but trying to answer your questions - my jaw doesn't feel stuck per se, but it's definitely been difficult to chew food lately. My face feels mostly normal till I try to smile or make expressions - that's when it feels weird and contorted. As for the tetanus shot, I honestly can't remember the last time I had one. My memory's a bit foggy right now with all this stress.

Your symptoms don't fit classic tetanus—true lockjaw means you physically cannot open your mouth more than a finger's width, and tetanus muscle spasms are severe, sustained, and painful, not just "weird when smiling." The timeline and exposure also don't match. However, difficulty chewing, facial changes, and your other symptoms (fevers, breathing issues, palpitations) still warrant medical evaluation to rule out other causes.

**You should see a doctor in person today or tomorrow**—urgent care or your student health center can assess you. Mention all your symptoms, especially the fevers and breathing difficulty. They can also update your tetanus vaccine if needed (adults need boosters every 10 years).

A few more questions to clarify:

1. Are the fevers documented with a thermometer, and if so, how high?
2. Is the shortness of breath happening at rest, or only with exertion or anxiety?
3. Have you had any recent illness, tick bites, or other injuries besides the shaving cut?

Wow, okay. This is a lot to take in but thank you for explaining. As for the fevers, yes, I've been using a digital thermometer and they've been around 101-102°F. The shortness of breath is mostly when I'm anxious or stressed but occasionally when I'm just sitting or lying down. And no, no recent illnesses or bites that I can think of. The shaving cut was the only thing. I'll make sure to go to the health center first thing in the morning.

Good—going to the health center tomorrow is the right move. Fevers of 101–102°F with your other symptoms need evaluation for possible infection or other medical causes, not tetanus. The shortness of breath and palpitations sound anxiety-related, especially given your panic about tetanus, but they should still be checked.

**Tonight: if you develop severe difficulty breathing, chest pain, inability to swallow, or true inability to open your mouth, go to the ER immediately.**

When you're seen tomorrow, ask about:
1. A full exam to find any source of fever (throat, lungs, etc.)
2. Updating your tetanus vaccine (Tdap booster)
3. Support for anxiety management—panic attacks can cause many of the symptoms you're experiencing (palpitations, breathing difficulty, muscle tension)

One last clarification: have you noticed any actual wounds, redness, swelling, or pus anywhere on your body (including that shaving cut site), or has everything healed normally?

I appreciate your detailed responses, they are really helping. My shaving cut healed up pretty normally, no redness or pus that I remember. But now that you mentioned it, I do have a small area on my leg that's been kind of itchy and swollen for a couple of days. I thought it was a mosquito bite or something but it might be worth mentioning to the doctor tomorrow.

That's helpful to know—mention the leg area to the doctor tomorrow, as localized infections can sometimes cause fever. It's likely unrelated to tetanus, but any wound or skin issue should be examined when you have unexplained fevers.

**Summary:** Your symptoms don't match tetanus, but you need evaluation for the fevers and that leg swelling. Anxiety is likely driving many of your other symptoms (palpitations, breathing difficulty, muscle tension). The health center visit tomorrow is appropriate—don't delay if things worsen tonight (see my earlier red flags).

**Plan for tomorrow:**
1. Full exam including the leg swelling and any other skin changes
2. Possible blood work or other tests depending on exam findings
3. Tdap booster if overdue
4. Discussion about anxiety management strategies

Try to stay calm tonight—tetanus is not your problem here. Focus on slow, deep breathing if panic symptoms flare. Is there anything else about your current symptoms that feels urgent or that I haven't addressed?

Hi hope you can helpive been getting chest pains, not severe but a constant pain, can happen when im just resting but has also happened when im exercising, it continues through to my back as well. Given your family history and the fact that chest pain occurs both at rest and with exercise, we need to take this seriously. Chest pain radiating to the back with a strong cardiac family history warrants urgent evaluation—I recommend you go to an emergency department or call emergency services today for an ECG, cardiac enzymes, and proper assessment. Heart attacks can present exactly this way, and we cannot rule out serious causes remotely.

Before you go, a few quick questions: How old are you, and do you have any known conditions like high blood pressure, diabetes, or high cholesterol? When did these pains start, and how long does each episode typically last? Do you have any shortness of breath, nausea, sweating, or arm/jaw pain with the chest discomfort?

You're right to be worried—this pattern is concerning. Chest pain doesn't have to be severe to be cardiac, especially with your age, hypertension, and very strong family history. The left arm ache makes this even more suspicious. Please go to the emergency department now or call an ambulance—don't drive yourself. You need an ECG, troponin blood test, and likely further cardiac workup today.

Are you currently taking your blood pressure medication regularly? Do you smoke, and have you had your cholesterol checked? Any recent cocaine or stimulant use?

Yes, I've been taking my blood pressure medication regularly. I quit smoking about five years ago and I've never used cocaine or any stimulants. As for my cholesterol, I can't recall when was the last time I had it checked. This is all getting a bit scary, I never thought it could be this serious. I'll call an ambulance right away.

Excellent decision—calling an ambulance is the right move. While waiting, chew one adult aspirin (325 mg) if you have it and aren't allergic, and stay calm and seated. Tell the paramedics about your family history, hypertension, and that the pain radiates to your back and left arm.

This may turn out to be something less serious, but given your profile, we can't take chances. Once you're evaluated and stabilized, make sure they check your cholesterol and discuss long-term prevention. Stay safe, and don't hesitate—get help now.

Okay, I'll do as you recommend. I think I got some aspirin in the medicine cabinet. I'll make sure to tell the paramedics all that you've told me. I appreciate your help and advice. You're doing exactly the right thing—stay as calm as you can, and help is on the way. Chew that aspirin now if you found it, and try to stay seated and still while you wait. The paramedics will take excellent care of you, and the hospital team will figure out what's going on and get you the right treatment.

Once this is sorted, we'll make sure you have a solid plan to protect your heart going forward. You've got this—hang in there, and please follow up to let me know how things go. Stay safe.
